work.p: This manuscript bears a distant resemblance to the preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass. See, for instance, the line: "It is the chosen tongue to express growth faith self-esteem freedom justice equality friendliness amplitude prudence decision and courage" (1855, p. xii).

titleStmt.title: that it fibre and strengthen
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive.

notesStmt.note: Whitman probably drafted this manuscript in the early 1850s as he was composing the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. The ideas and some of the phrasing in the manuscript are similar to ideas and phrasing used in the preface to that edition.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: [I say the stars are not echoes]
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Transcribed from The Walt Whitman Archive I: Whitman Manuscripts at the Library of Congress, ed. Joel Myerson (New York: Garland, 1993), 2:522-523; Major American Authors on CD-Rom: Walt Whitman (Westport, CT: Primary Source Media, 1997). The transcription was then checked against digital images of the original.
Draft lines of poetry on the back of this manuscript leaf relate to early versions of "Song of Myself" and "To Think of Time."

revisionDesc.change: created new file out of loc.00042

div1.ab:
—that it fibres and strengthens and vital all good things, and
that which is good, and weaken erase all which is bad.—Compulsion, on the other hand is a temporary support, gained at the price of much bad feeling and reaction.—

ab.seg:
schools—proud of and valuing it for
its good name works of art architecture parks, ornaments, aquaducts and avenues and the perfection of its civilization and communities
—and possessed
Every one of these officers should be possessed with the genuine eternal American ideas of liberty, freedom amplitude and native courage.—

It is all nonsense to suppose fancy that the sphere of these fine such fine traits most necessarily can only be on some diffused and higher and more diffused and commanding scale, as Governor or Cabinet Senator or President.—
The right sort of men will exemplify them just as well here directly at our doors or in our City Hall.—
